thread.title_full: Appeal Court ruling could give £3.3bn boost to same-sex couples' pensions

title: Appeal Court ruling could give £3.3bn boost to same-sex couples' pensions
text:
0.00 0.00 
Gay and lesbian savers do not have the legal right to inherit partners' pensions accrued before 2005 - but this could change 
A landmark court ruling on whether a gay man can legally inherit his partner's full retirement fund could boost same-sex couples’ pensions by £3.3bn - or £5,714 each. 
Tomorrow the Court of Appeal will decide whether the man, who is legally entitled to pass only £500 of his pension on to his partner when he dies, should instead be allowed to bequeath £41,000, the same amount he could leave to a wife. 
A ruling in the man's favour would force every employer in the country to change its rules. Lawyers describe the case as the most important concerning sexual discrimination in pensions since the 1990s. 
• EU to push for same-sex marriages to be accepted across continent 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) relates to a legal loophole that leaves hundreds of thousands of gay and lesbian couples who are married and in civil partnerships worse off in retirement than everyone else. 
This is because, as the law stands, they are not entitled to inherit company pension income accrued by their partners before 2005. 
Same-sex couples were given the legal right to inherit each other's pensions in 2005, but only for money saved after this date. 
Around 70,000 workers are expected to leave behind a same-sex partner when they die and data from the TUC suggests that they would be £5,714 better off if they were allowed to inherit their partner's full pension. 
Some major British employers, including Shell (LSE: RDSB.L - news ) and Telefonica UK, the owner of O2, have voluntarily surpassed the legal minimum and already give same-sex couples the same benefits as husbands and wives. However, it is estimated that one in four final salary pension schemes does not do more than the law requires. 
A spokesman for Stonewall, the gay rights campaign group, said: "The current situation is unfair - equality should not be denied on the basis of cost. Stonewall works with employers to ensure they recognise and act upon this loophole, and actively backdate pensions to provide equal benefits in their pension schemes." 
Alastair Meeks, a partner at law firm Pinsent Masons, said: “This is potentially very important for older individuals, who could stand to gain life-changing amounts from a change in the rules. However, as far as many employers are concerned, this is just one more cost they could do without.”
